docs.abstract: To someone who's spent the last few years thinking about the American food chain, a visit to Manhattan's Union Square in the spring of 2006 feels a little like a visit to Paris in the spring of 1968 must have felt, or perhaps closer to the mark, Peoples Park in Berkeley in the summer of [...]
docs.lead_paragraph: To someone who's spent the last few years thinking about the American food chain, a visit to Manhattan's Union Square in the spring of 2006 feels a little like a visit to Paris in the spring of 1968 must have felt, or perhaps closer to the mark, Peoples Park in Berkeley in the summer of 1969. Not that I was in either of those places at the appointed historical hour, or that the stakes are quite as high. (Isn't hyperbole an earmark of Internet literary style? O.K. then.) But today in these few square blocks of lower Manhattan, change is in the air, and the future - at least the future of food - is up for grabs.

headline.print_headline: Bottlers Agree To a School Ban On Sweet Drinks
headline.main: Bottlers Agree to a School Ban on Sweet Drinks

byline.original: By MARIAN BURROS  and MELANIE WARNER

docs.lead_paragraph: The top three soft-drink companies said that they would start removing sweetened drinks from schools.
docs.snippet: The top three soft-drink companies said that they would start removing sweetened drinks from schools.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Bolivia Threatens to Seize Energy Companies' Assets Bolivian authorities said they planned to scour the financial records of foreign energy companies and for the first time explicitly threatened to seize their assets if new contracts giving the state greater control over the industry could not be negotiated. A13 War-Torn Chechnya Rebuilds After more than a decade of war, banditry and disorder, restoration efforts are taking hold in Grozny, Chechnya, a city largely destroyed by years of fighting between Russia and Chechen separatists. A1 Iran Draft Resolution Circulated Britain and France circulated a draft United Nations Security Council resolution demanding that Iran give up nuclear activities that the West contends are aimed at building bombs. A11 A New Obstacle for Hamas Financial institutions in the West Bank with ties to the American banking system have stopped accepting international money transfers to the Hamas-led government, providing an unexpected obstacle to the government's efforts to raise cash. A3 U.S. Takes Role in Sudan Talks American officials took a forceful role in peace negotiations between Darfur rebels and the government of Sudan, pushing through revisions of a proposed agreement in an effort to restart the stalled talks, senior State Department officials said. A8 Dozens of Iraqis Found Dead More than 50 Iraqis were killed or found dead, as Iraqi leaders struggled to form a unified government that they hope can diminish the insurgency and ease violence between Sunnis and Shiites. A11 NATIONAL A14-27 Moussaoui Receives Life For Role in Sept. 11 Attacks A federal jury rejected the death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui, apparently concluding that he played only a minor role in Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and giving weight to his troubled upbringing. He will instead spend the rest of his life in a Colorado federal prison. A1 Schools to Lose Soft Drinks As the concern for childhood obesity grows, the three top soda companies said they would remove drinks like Coke and Pepsi from school cafeterias and vending machines. A1 Guilty Plea in Bribery Case Vernon L. Jackson, the chairman of a Kentucky-based technology firm, pleaded guilty to charges of bribing an unnamed member of Congress in an investigation that has centered on Representative William J. Jefferson, a Louisiana Democrat. A14 The House narrowly passed legislation that requires lobbyists to disclose more of their activities, increases penalties for violations and requires lawmakers and their aides to attend ethics training. A19 Officials Question Flu Plan As the country braces for a potential outbreak of a virulent strain of bird flu, health officials said they welcomed the Bush administration's latest plan for dealing with a pandemic flu outbreak, but some complained that it failed to provide the money needed to pay for it. A20 President Bush threatened again to veto a Senate bill that would pay for the Iraq war and Gulf Coast recovery if its price tag is more than his ceiling of $92.2 billion for the war and hurricane recovery, with an additional $2.3 billion to prepare for a possible flu pandemic. A19 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 New York Wants DNA For Crimes Big and Small A push to require all convicted criminals in New York State to submit their DNA to a central database is gaining crucial support in Albany, where officials say it could create the most comprehensive DNA collection system in the nation. B1 Yale Controversy Reignited A special student at Yale University who was once a roving ambassador for the Taliban regime in Afghanistan has applied for admission to a degree-granting program, putting new pressures on university officials in an emotionally charged political debate over his presence at Yale. B1 Buildings at Center of Battle The 15 buildings in Brooklyn that were gutted in a 10-alarm fire were at the center of a complex real estate deal gone wrong between veteran developers who were themselves the targets of neighborhood preservationists hoping to secure the historic district's legacy as a landmark. B1 SCIENCE/HEALTH Quake Sparks Tsunami Fears Two weeks before a scheduled test of a warning system for tsunamis around the Pacific basin, a magnitude-7.9 earthquake off the islands of Tonga provided a more urgent, unscheduled test, briefly spurring tsunami fears. A12 ARTS E1-12 Picasso Nets $95.2 Million A Picasso portrait, ''Dora Maar With Cat,'' sold for $95.2 million at a Sotheby's auction, the second-highest amount ever paid for a painting. B4 BUSINESS DAY C1-15 Gathering of Drug Data Computerized lists showing which doctors are prescribing what drugs have long been considered the most potent weapon in pharmaceutical sales. But some doctors consider the data gathering an intrusion, and states are taking action. A1 Cable Helps Time Warner Cable television delivered a strong first quarter for Time Warner, more than offsetting worsening results at its AOL unit, the company said. C1 Raytheon C.E.O. Penalized The board of the Raytheon Company punished the chief executive, William H. Swanson, for plagiarizing parts of a management book ''Swanson's Unwritten Rules of Management,'' by taking away almost $1 million from his 2006 compensation. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: Due process; Medicare's shrinking options; the letter about dying down below; funny money. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E10 TV Listings E11 Crossword E10 Weather C16 Obituaries A29

headline.print_headline: Study Says Older Americans Are Less Healthy Than British
headline.main: Study Says Older Americans Are Less Healthy Than British

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. spends more than twice as much on health care, but Americans 55 and over are sicker than their British counterparts.
docs.snippet: The U.S. spends more than twice as much on health care, but Americans 55 and over are sicker than their British counterparts.

headline.main: Study Says Older Americans Are Less Healthy Than British

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans 55 and over are much sicker than their British counterparts even though the United States spends more than twice as much per person on health care as Britain, researchers said Tuesday. Writing in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers from University College, London, also seemed to confirm stereotypes tossed across the Atlantic, concluding that Americans are prone to obesity while Britons drink too much.
docs.snippet: Americans 55 and over are much sicker than their British counterparts even though the United States spends more than twice as much per person on health care as Britain, researchers said Tuesday.     Writing in The Journal of the American Medical...

headline.print_headline: Older Americans Much Sicker Than the English, Study Finds
headline.main: Older Americans Sicker Than the English, Study Says

docs.lead_paragraph: The disparities could not be ascribed to the two countries' different health care systems, said one of the authors of the study.
docs.snippet: The disparities could not be ascribed to the two countries' different health care systems, said one of the authors of the study.

headline.print_headline: Cadaver Skin Fills the Gap In Burn Cases
headline.main: Cadaver Skin Fills the Gap in Burn Cases

docs.lead_paragraph: Cadaver skin has long been the preferred option for a patient with the most severe burns until a graft of the patient's own skin can be applied.
docs.snippet: Cadaver skin has long been the preferred option for a patient with the most severe burns until a graft of the patient's own skin can be applied.
